text:
Check out this experiment. You might have
seen it in chemistry class or on late night
TV. But have you ever seen it… in slow-motion?

This reaction is often called the Elephant
Toothpaste demo. Probably because an elephant

needs a lot of toothpaste? Who cares. Here
it is filmed at 1000 frames per second.

What’s really happening here is a great
demonstration of catalysts, things that speed
up or kickstart chemical reactions.

Chemistry professor Matt Hartings is adding
a potassium iodide catalyst and some detergent

soap to a solution of 30 percent hydrogen
peroxide. That’s the lab-grade stuff -- you
can’t get that at the store.

Chemically speaking, hydrogen peroxide looks
like water except that it's got an extra oxygen

atom squeezed into it. The extra oxygen makes
it unstable and potentially dangerous. We

actually use this stuff to kill off bacteria
in open wounds.

Peroxide eventually decomposes into regular
old water and oxygen gas. That DOES NOT mean

you can drink it. Don’t. Anyway, it’s
a very slow reaction. Slower than paint drying.

Potassium iodide catalyzes the reaction, converting
the hydrogen peroxide into water and oxygen
gas in mere seconds instead of years.

This super-fast reaction is exothermic. In
other words, it releases energy in the form

of heat. Some of the water gets converted
to steam because of that heat. That steam

expands quickly, mixes with the soap and the
oxygen gas, and all of this hot air gets shot

out the top of the flask together in a hot
foamy mess.
Let’s see it one more time. While we watch, a reminder to be safe. Hydrogen peroxide

is corrosive to the eyes, skin and lungs,
especially the 30 percent mix we’re using
here. Always use gloves and goggles.

You can thank catalysts for this cool footage.
Without them, crucial chemical reactions needed

to drive your car, grow your food and keep
you alive would happen way more slowly. And
who wants to wait? Or die?

Big thanks to Matt Hartings at American University
for the help. Let us know in the comments

what chemistry experiments you want to see
in slow motion.  Thanks for watching.
